Question: Today is Friday, 26 April, 2013, and 16:15 hours in the afternoon. This
interview 1s being conducted with Mr. Bowen, and it re — to celebrate the United
States Holocaust Memorial Museum’s 20" anniversary. Mr. Bowen, tell us your
full name and when and where you were born.

Answer: Chasten L. Bowen. I was born in Nevada, Missouri on July the 12",
1924.
Q: And did you grow up there?

A: I was there til I was about nine years old. I moved to Garden City, Kansas,
cause my mother was a nurse 1n a hospital there. She took a job there in kind of,
depression days. She was there a few years and I was about 13, I think, and she got
a job in California. My father got a job at Chrysler assembly plant in Los Angeles,
so they went to California. I followed, with my brother about two months later, and
that’s where I’ve been all my life.
Q: How old were you when you moved out to California?

A: Let’s see, I’m trying to think, let’s see, that was about — I think I was about 14 -
15 years old.
Q: Okay, so you went to sc —

Q: — you went to school out in California.

A: I went to school in — in California. Went to high school, and then I went to the

know, and was interesting to see the — how long the radio — how far you could reach

A: No, I didn’t have any problem. I liked th — I — I’m — I liked to — I liked both,

chocolate bar, and gave this little kid. And the mother scolded me for tormenting

A: Cause the little kids would — you’d go up and down the street and the little kids

A: Was kind of interesting city. I was there one time when — just after a V-1 hit

and different place in London and I — interesting time. I — I thought I was — lost my

A: No.

A: No. No, didn’t have time.

A: Well, quite a bit of training, because in — 1n the radio thing, the Americans had

went about th — I think it was a couple weeks of training, cross training with the

Q: What sort of aircraft did you have, and where were you 1n that aircraft?

A: I was the radio operator by the center of the aircraft, just behind the bomb bays,
and I had gun above the head. And it was a B-17G, we just got the Gs model in
when I was there. And I always used to go down the lines and see a lot of planes
that come back were pretty shot up, and we wondered how they flew, and part of

Q: Was it frightening?

A: I never really seemed to get too excited about that. I always thought — I always
figured that if the plane went down, my idea was I’d — I'd go down with it, and it’d

Q: First combat experience — first flew — no — not — what — your first flight that you

A: I don’t remember the exact day that we had there. I think there was training
flights that we went just to the coast, turn around, come back, three of them. And

then on the day of the — the bomb, when I fir — when I was shot down, why we got

different colored flare and they fire it off up there at altitude and then you

the horizontal stabilizers rather, and they just dive straight down. The British
developed a technique to keep those from coming into England. They had a fighter

Wasn’t — I guess it was too heavy to be a real good fighter like the Spitfire. And
they would send those out over the Channel when they hear — see these things
coming in, cause they flew at a certain altitude, and the Typhoons would fly along

the side of them and flap the wing on them and tip the gyro in, and they just spiral

hundreds of those darn B-I1s.

A: Yeah, well they just fly alongside. They were doing about maybe, I don’t know,
300 miles an hour, 250 mile an hour, fly alongside and just flap the wing, you

Q: Right.

A: So it was a clever idea. Didn’t take much you know, and the air — Typhoons

A: Oh yeah, I remember going over and seeing the — the coastline and — and seeing

no-no, we — we made a 360 degree turn and went back to same initial point and

So the tail gunner says, about 300 yards off the tail, had a burst. Next one through

something. But you change your mind rather quickly when that happens, so I — guys

you could hear them, and there’s — their canister they carry with them is — their gas
